verses.text: All wisdom comes from the Lord, and is with him forever.
verses.comment: This verse immediately roots wisdom in God's own being, emphasizing that wisdom is not attainable apart from Him. The connection to James 1:5 shows that God is the source of wisdom in both Testaments, inviting us to seek Him for understanding.

verses.text: The sand of the sea, and the drops of rain, and the days of eternity—who can count them?
verses.comment: This rhetorical question highlights the infinite nature of creation and the limitations of human understanding compared to God’s omniscience.

verses.text: Heaven’s height, earth’s breadth, the depth of the abyss, and wisdom—who can search them out?
verses.comment: The realities of creation are beyond our measure, paralleling the inscrutable nature of wisdom itself. This recognizes God's sovereignty over all things.

verses.text: Wisdom was created before all things, and prudent understanding from eternity.
verses.comment: Here, wisdom is personified as pre-existent, which foreshadows the Word in John’s prologue, interpreted as Christ Himself who is the fullness of divine wisdom.

verses.text: The root of wisdom—to whom has it been revealed? Who understands her great ways?
verses.comment: This verse maintains that only God truly comprehends wisdom’s depth, hinting that man must receive wisdom by revelation.

verses.text: There is one who is wise, greatly to be feared, sitting upon his throne—the Lord.
verses.comment: God alone is supremely wise, enthroned as King over all. The fear of the Lord is the starting point of true wisdom, as affirmed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: He created her, saw her, and measured her. He poured her out upon all his works.
verses.comment: Wisdom is presented as both created and distributed by God, reflecting how creation is ordered wisely.

verses.text: She is with all flesh, according to his gift, and he gives her to those who love him.
verses.comment: Wisdom is universally available but especially granted to those who are faithful in love to God. This anticipates the theme of grace given through obedience.

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is glory and pride, happiness and a crown of rejoicing.
verses.comment: Reverence for God brings honor and joy, depicted as a crown—an image later echoed in New Testament rewards (see James 1:12).

verses.text: The fear of the Lord delights the heart, and gives gladness, joy, and long life.
verses.comment: Obedience and awe toward God lead to deep joy and the blessing of life—spiritually and even temporally.

verses.text: Those who fear the Lord will have a good end; on the day of their death, they shall be blessed.
verses.comment: This anticipates the Christian teaching on the hope of a blessed end for the faithful, foreshadowing resurrection and eternal life.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is the beginning of wisdom; it was created with the faithful in the womb.
verses.comment: Wisdom is linked with faithful living from the very start; this echoes Proverbs and implies God's presence shaping the faithful from their origins.

verses.text: She has built her nest among human beings for all eternity, and will be entrusted to their offspring.
verses.comment: Wisdom dwelling among people points to God's intention for ongoing relationship and revelation throughout generations.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is the fullness of wisdom; she fills them with her fruits.
verses.comment: The fruitful life of wisdom connects to the spiritual fruits found in Christian teaching, showing wisdom's effect on character and action.

verses.text: She will fill every house she enters, and storehouses with her treasures.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings abundance, both spiritual and practical, bringing prosperity where she dwells.

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is the crown of wisdom, forming peace and sound health. He rained down knowledge and understanding, and exalted those who possess her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is holistic, affecting body, soul, and community. The theme of ‘exaltation’ hints at God's particular favor upon the wise.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is devotion of heart, which gives peace and life.
verses.comment: A heartfelt reference to the transformative power of true worship, which bestows inner tranquility and spiritual life.

verses.text: It will be a guard and a strong support, a shelter from scorching heat and protection from noonday sun; it will preserve from falling and keep from wickedness.
verses.comment: Fear of the Lord acts as a safeguard, providing security and moral protection.

verses.text: God pours out wisdom’s knowledge and sound understanding, exalting the glory of those who embrace her.
verses.comment: God is the active giver, freely granting wisdom and honor to those who receive her.

verses.text: To fear the Lord is the root of wisdom; her branches are long life.
verses.comment: This continued imagery shows that a life rooted in God leads to spiritual fruitfulness and longevity.

verses.text: Unjust wrath cannot be justified, for its falling weight is a stumbling block.
verses.comment: The text warns against unchecked anger, consistent both with wisdom tradition and the call to be peacemakers (see Matthew 5:9).

verses.text: Those who are patient stay calm at the right moment, and in the end they will be happy.
verses.comment: Patience is prized in both Wisdom literature and the New Testament—endurance brings true happiness.

verses.text: He hides his words for a time, but the lips of many declare his insight.
verses.comment: Divine wisdom may be concealed for a season but becomes evident to the community—echoing the importance of tradition and communal faithfulness.

verses.text: A wise saying is found in the treasures of wisdom, but for the sinner, reverence for God is despised.
verses.comment: Respect for God and humility are required to truly grasp wise teaching—sinful pride rejects both.

verses.text: If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the Lord will supply her generously.
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s commandments is foundational for the reception of wisdom. This has echoes in Christ’s teaching, stressing the unity of love and obedience.

verses.text: For wisdom and discipline are the fear of the Lord, and faithfulness and humility are his delight.
verses.comment: Humility and discipline are partnered with wisdom, showing a heart posture that pleases God.

verses.text: Do not disobey the fear of the Lord; do not draw near to him with a divided heart.
verses.comment: True devotion must be sincere and undivided—a lesson reinforced constantly throughout both Testaments.

verses.text: Do not be a hypocrite before others, and guard your lips.
verses.comment: Both Old and New Testament warn against external religion without inward sincerity. Guarding one's speech is also a recurring theme.

verses.text: Do not exalt yourself, or you may fall and bring shame on yourself. The Lord will reveal your secrets and utterly humiliate you, and cast you down in the midst of the assembly, because you did not come in the fear of the Lord, and your heart was full of deception.
verses.comment: Humility is stressed as essential in religious life and leadership. Self-exaltation leads to downfall, links to Christ’s parables about humility and being last to be first.

verses.text: Because you did not approach the Lord in reverence, and your heart was full of deceit.
verses.comment: Approaching God requires sincerity and integrity of heart. This theme is foundational for entering into deeper relationship with Him through authentic worship and faith.
